awd_titl_txt: Use of Legitimating Strategies in Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the legitimation of an institutionalized but contested practice.  The methods used by its proponents to defend the practice, the content of their defense, and how this is covered by media are analyzed.  This study advances understanding of the strategies and techniques used to influence public opinion and policy outcomes in an environment in which both the amount and complexity of information are rapidly increasing.  Findings from this study will be valuable to society by increasing public knowledge of democratic decision-making in an area that has both fiscal consequences and consequences for social opportunity.

Qualitative data are drawn from public documents and narratives from 1995 to 2018 of three groups with diverse interests, and from interviews with members of these groups.  These data are analyzed using the theoretical concept of frames.  Messages derived from the public documents of the three groups are compared to media coverage of them.  Triangulation among data sources is employed to reduce bias.  This study enhances understanding of legitimation processes by focusing on the legitimation of established but contested and unstable social practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In terms of intellectual merit, our study contributed to sociological scholarship on racial inequality and immigration by investigating how mass incarceration, a racial caste system, expanded to include immigration control, and the critical role privatization played in the expansion. It also extended theories of legitimacy by examining narratives about immigration control over time and from multiple and divergent institutional perspectives (including government, advocacy organizations, media, and corporations). This examination of how proponents and opponents of immigration control reproduced and disrupted systems of inequality offered insights on the strategic use of frames in the face of institutional vulnerability and on the “success” of legitimation strategies. 

Our analyses of news media showed that, in contrast to existing research, narratives rarely vilify immigrants to justify the privatization of immigration control. Instead, narratives involve a subtler technique that we call the apathy strategy—the active avoidance of discussing immigrants and inequality, as though the oppressed or oppressive practices do not matter or exist. This strategy offers powerful groups critical distance from the groups most adversely affected by their words and actions and allows groups to enjoy the privileges of inequality without having to acknowledge the inequality itself, let alone their role in the production of the inequality (Ebert et al. 2020).

In another study on an analysis of data derived from the news media in two distinct periods, we examined if Trump’s embrace of explicit racism altered aspects of the discursive opportunity structure (DOS) of privatized immigration control. We found that rationalizations of immigration control do not reflect the racism of the Trump administration, and opponents of immigration control did not publicly criticize the institutional racism inherent in the industry. However, the transformation of the DOS appears to have inspired more direct and confrontational frames, resulting in a more polarized public debate (Estrada et al. 2020). 

Another study considered how the global pandemic and growth in Black mobilization affected the positions of challengers and proponents of immigration detention, including ACLU, private prison companies, and ICE. We found that these global events did not appear to significantly alter the public conversation about immigration control, as evidenced by the consistency of narratives dating back to the pre-pandemic era. The ACLU’s criticisms of inhumane conditions in immigration detention resembled those from its pre-pandemic advocacy. Private prison companies emphasized their roles as ordinary businesses rather than detention managers during the pandemic, just as they had before the crisis. ICE, however, manufactured an alternative storyline, emphasizing “COVID fraud” as the real threat to the “Homeland.” We discuss how these organizations’ indifference towards structural racism contributes to racial apathy and how the obliviousness and irresponsibility of ICE and private prison companies resembles white ignorance (Liao et al. 2021).

Concerning the study’s broader impacts, we shared our skills and knowledge as researchers through engagement and service with the public. Drs. Estrada and Liao participated in multiple public forums and other community events. Dr. Estrada works with Syracuse Immigrant and Refugee Defense Network, an organization that provides direct assistance to the local migrant community as well as engages in state-level advocacy efforts. Dr. Liao worked with Rochester Rapid Response Network, the local chapter of a national grassroots organization focusing on supporting undocumented folks facing the threat of detention and deportation. Dr. Ebert also volunteered at the South Texas Family Residential Center in Dilley, TX, working with women and children who sought asylum in the United States.

We also made our research available to a general audience. In December 2020, Drs. Ebert and Liao organized a virtual public conference on racialization and immigration. More than 100 participants registered and 20 migration scholars shared their research with an audience both in and outside academia. Ten papers from the conference were published in a double issue of American Behavioral Scientist (co-edited by Drs. Ebert and Liao). Additionally, we published our work in an open access peer-reviewed journal. We also publicized our research through guest posts on Contexts.org, the “public face of sociology.” For example, Dr. Ebert, along with an undergraduate student, posted a piece on immigration control. 

We also shared our research and expertise within our respective universities. We played an active role in training the next generation of social scientists by serving as mentors to graduate and undergraduate research assistants. We encouraged, taught, and guided our assistants throughout the entire tenure of the funding cycle. We also shared our research with students, campus organizations, and other university personnel. For example, Dr. Liao has co-created a course on borders and immigration that she will teach in Spring 2023 at RIT, and Ebert taught sociology of immigration several times and made it an official course on record at NCSU. Dr. Estrada has served as a guest speaker in several courses at SUNY-Oswego. Drs. Ebert and Estrada presented our research to multiple student groups at their respective universities.
